metadata.case_name: State of Gujarat v. Messrs. Kailash Engineering Co.

facts.text: Messrs. Kailash Engineering Co. (respondent) was an engineering concern having workshop at Morvi on meter gauge section of Western Railway.
Respondent obtained contract from Western Railway Administration for construction of III class passenger coaches on conditions of tender, reduced to writing as agreement.
Respondent constructed three coaches and submitted bill certified by Railway on October 4, 1958; net value Rs. 1,22,035/- received.
After receipt, respondent wrote to Additional Collector of Sales Tax under S.27 Bombay Sales Tax Act, 1953 requesting ruling that it was works contract, not sale, no sales-tax payable.
Additional Collector held: (1) transaction covered by bill is sale; (2) tax payable. Both against respondent.
Appeal to Gujarat Sales Tax Tribunal failed.

Tribunal referred to Gujarat High Court: Whether on proper construction of agreement, work under Contract Certificate No. M/60 1 B-PRTN dated 4th October 1958 for building, erecting and furnishing 3 B.G. Coaches over chassis supplied by Railway is works contract not sale, or transaction of sale.
High Court answered in favour of respondent: transaction was works contract, not sale.
Contract clause: ownership in plant and materials vests in Railway as soon as brought to site.
Another clause: on removal of contractor or rescission, Railway entitled to take possession of materials, tools etc.
Clause 29: Contractor liable if materials lost, stolen etc., despite ownership in Railway.
Preamble and clauses describe contract for work of building, erecting, furnishing coach bodies on Broad Gauge underframes belonging to Railway.
Tribunal held ownership passed only when completed and handed over, so contract for supply of coach bodies.

legal_issues.text: Whether on proper construction of the agreement as a whole and its general conditions and specification, the work done and covered by Contract Certificates No. M/60 1 B-PRTN dated 4th October 1958 for performance of works of building, erecting and furnishing 3 B.G. Coaches over chassis supplied by Railway is a works contract not amounting to sale, or a transaction of sale.

petitioner_arguments.text: Transaction is sale of coach bodies, as ownership passed only when completed and handed over; amount received as sale consideration.
Relied on Patnaik & Co. v. State of Orissa where supply of bus bodies held to be sale.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Patnaik & Co. v. State of Orissa

respondent_arguments.text: Contract is for performance of work of building, erecting and furnishing coach bodies on underframes already belonging to Railway; ownership vests in Railway as soon as materials brought to site; respondent acted as agent.

court_reasoning.text: Terms show ownership in materials vests in Railway on bringing to site; respondent to erect and furnish; property in ready coach bodies vests automatically, never in respondent.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Risk on Railway but contractor liable per clause 29 as in custody.

court_reasoning.text: Contract entire and indivisible for carrying out works; no sale of materials or coach bodies.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Unfinished bodies property of Railway from earliest stage.

court_reasoning.text: Distinguishes Patnaik: here coach bodies not described as units to supply; no delivery of ready bodies; unfinished treated as Railway property; special liability clause due to ownership vesting early.

holdings.text: Contract is works contract which did not involve any sale; property vested in Railway even during construction.

precedents_cited.case_name: Patnaik & Co. v. State of Orissa
precedents_cited.relevance: Held supply of bus bodies as sale; distinguished due to different contract terms on ownership, delivery, and risk.

statutes_cited.name: Bombay Sales Tax Act III of 1953
statutes_cited.relevance: Respondent sought ruling under this that no sales-tax payable as works contract.

outcome.summary: Appeal against High Court decision fails; High Court correctly held transaction was works contract not sale; appeal dismissed with costs.

key_quotes.text: "This was, therefore, clearly a works contract which did not involve any sale."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "the respondent, in purchasing those materials, was acting more or less in the capacity of an agent for the Railway."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains why no sale despite purchase by respondent.
